pros: Staff is good at teaching
cons: HR/admin could use work with hiring/management

pros: Benefits, weekends off, ability to pick up overtime
cons: Everything. This job was the worst position I’ve ever held in my life. They will work you down & not support you even a little bit. The manager is rude and out of touch. They use Microsoft teams which is highly abused and a breeding ground for constant nagging & negativity. The pay is awful for the work that is asked. Leadership will tell you they care and they understand the workload but they don’t as they will constantly berate you on why things are not done. They will minimize the clinic issues and use you as their dumping ground to place blame. Don’t waste your time. Also, good luck getting promoted or getting out of this position if desired- they do not hire within & will not promote even if you are qualified.

job_title: Senior Clinic Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great benefits and great team members. It is a blessing being able to work with such a hard group of people especially during the pandemic. Every day is different and you get to immerse yourself in a field with different healthcare professionals. As someone wanting to dive deeper into the healthcare field, this is a stepping stone experience you need to see and be a part of. Working here long-term also allows you to build a bond with patients. You become a part of their healing journey and become an advocate for them.
cons: Some leaders are truly terrible. Not only do they take credit for your work, but they also attack you and nitpick as if they truly cared about your clinic when those above them are rounding your clinic. You will not get recognition for your work. On busy days, nurses will literally throw a fit and get mad at you if you were to tell them that their provider's patient is in the clinic. There's a lack of training and development. If you have team members who are willing to help you grow, then take advantage of that opportunity and recognize them for their wealth of knowledge.

review_title: Great Place to Gain Experience and Grow
pros: This is a residency clinic for new providers out of medical school. With that being said there is an energy of learning new things. You tend to feel like it is ok to ask questions and it is ok to not know the answer but just ask someone so you can get the answer. There tends to be a good vibe and good comradery amongst the employees.
cons: Starting pay is not the best. You will need to negotiate. Especially for Medical Assistants

pros: Remote, decent benefits, good staff.
cons: None to complain about, I work from home.

pros: Advance practice advocates. Fair market compensation. Excellent benefits
cons: Like any larger organization, bogged down by politics and bureaucracy

review_title: Great pay & benefits but Overworked with limited resources
job_title: RN Care Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Pay and benefits are amazing. Great teams, dedicated to the priority of better care for our patients, willing to work across the network of physicians and other groups, flexibility with schedule, hybrid work environment, plenty of career growth opportunities, direct management is dedicated to helping staff and better the system.
cons: Overworked with limited resources and disconnected leadership, very complicated health system with a three part merger has caused silos in the organization. Delays in communication internally but also with patients trying to seek care.

pros: There isn’t much besides the benefits
cons: Everything else. The job, management, etc.

pros: Pay, benefits, and time off seem competitive with the market.
cons: Complex organizational structure between Fairview, the University of Minnesota, and UMPhysicians creates inefficiencies and confusion. HR and IT support is not great. Feels like higher level administration is more focused on productivity and generating revenue than quality care and the well-being of staff with employees expected to do more with less. Poor work-life balance.

job_title: Direct Patient Care Staff in Saint Paul, MN
pros: good benefits, good hours, decent community
cons: terrible PTO policy and sick leave

pros: Coworkers are great and healthcare is good!
cons: Pay is very low compared to other healthcare jobs in the area

pros: Value employees and good place to work
cons: No Cons to this place

pros: Good pay, nice environment, great managers.
cons: You have to pay for all of your CEU's on your own. Chronically understaffed.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great benefits Good team of coworkers
cons: Senior leadership is bulky. Fair pay is unclear. Provides no pay scales or ranges to employees.

review_title: Staff culture is amazing, management and company culture could use some serious work
job_title: Staff RN Operating Room in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Direct coworkers absolutely amazing, we make sure our culture amongst each other is positive, and everyone is super helpful, always willing to help out each other. In my position in the ambulatory surgery center I never work weekends or holidays, and I don't work call. I have fair and very little late shifts. I enjoy my job and my coworkers make the days fly by. Probably one of the best group of staff I've worked with.
cons:
Obvious favoritism by manager of certain employees
Due to merger with Fairview--poor leadership; "pick and choose" policies followed of Mhealth vs Fairview
Lazy direct management, lack of follow through
Inconsistent raises and pay
Very little career growth in certain positions
Money over staff concerns

job_title: Licensed Independent Clinical Social Worker (LICSW) in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Flexibility and autonomy in my schedule. Choice of remote or office work. Incredible benefits.
cons: This is a physician led company with roots in the medical model. As a result, social workers are not valued. A lot of education has been needed to teach the system the worth of clinical social workers working at the top of their licensure. Despite the incredible need for more social worker that are also able to generate revenue, funding for these positions is hard to come by.

pros: Benefits, schedule, patient load, coworkers
cons: Pay compared to WFMC, unclear business outlook

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Overall it's a decent company but I had a great manager, ymmv
cons: The ones who make the rules may still be a bit outdated requiring everyone to wear a uniform rather than just make the dress policy business or business casual. Dying of hair is getting to be a bit more relaxed but they still have rules on that.

job_title: Advance Practice Provider in Minneapolis, MN
pros: My patients and co-workers are amazing. The benefits are good too.
cons: The salary is below the market rate for Twin Cities

job_title: Social Work Care Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great Benefits, Decent Salary, Fun Coworkers
cons: Little to no Flexibility on Hours of Work, Work gets piled on when staffing shortages happen

pros: Wonderful physicians and support staff
cons: Poor company culture, high turnover (especially of minorities)

pros: Immediate coworkers support generally supportive depending where you work within the company. Pay is typically good, more rewarded in early start up and formative years.
cons: Focus from BOD’s going into later CEO focus on growth rates and visions rather than it’s employees on how to use them and grow and nourish. Upper management did not have the pulse on valuable employees. Let management with eagerness for power overrun value of employees with skill and determination. Turnover not a problem with the company as growth is the end result not the value of its employees. Top management degrades employees via gossip rather than sitting with employee with transparencies and structure to work out any potential issues to a point of corruption. Department heads have often been at odds with one another.

pros: Access to research opportunities. 401k contribution is great.
cons: Focus on clinical research often leaves other areas out of focus. Matrixed system is challenging to navigate, no roadmaps exist to help guide new employees

job_title: Family Nurse Practitioner in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Fair pay, good benefits, good work life balance
cons: Disorganized, inconsistent review structure, leadership is not present

review_title: If you want big promises with little follow through
job_title: Patient Intake Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Pay, benefits, work from home, great technical support
cons: lack of support from management, angry patient calls due to major delays in care or poor treatment from staff in clinic, little to no constructive feedback on performance, confusing protocol layout that is not updated as changes are made, nobody to provide support or answer questions during busy call times, cliques within pods, management that does not respond to emails or text messages

pros:
Very supportive of advance practice providers. 
Excellent benefits
cons: Minimal differential pay for weekends/holidays

pros:
Medical and dental and vision benefits 
Decent PTO
Getting recognized for hard work.
cons: the organization won’t hire what’s needed to provide accurate patient care.

Flexible and ability to work from home
Being salaried allows for some comp time throughout the week, on occasion
cons:
Yearly merit raises are inconsistent and no COLA raises factored in
Have to 'prove' your worth a raise- which can be frustrating

pros: Potential for team buildin that turns into friends
cons: Hectic in the pandemic era and no resources for burnt out staff

pros: Excellent benefits, flexibility with scheduled when needed,
cons: Management positions constantly changing and management framework

pros: Great patients and coworkers that make coming into work a great experience. Good benefits as well.
cons: Management tend to micromanage. Clinic Coordinators here don't seem to be paid as much compared to other healthcare systems in the area.

pros:
Awesome 401(k) contribution
Great, reasonable healthcare plans
Remote work opportunities
cons: Tuition reimbursement benefit could be better

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great benefits, providers are nice. Team like atmosphere.
cons: Just like most places staffing can be an issue.

review_title: Good place to work but improvements could be made
job_title: Lead Patient Relations Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Competitive salary, good benefits, work remote options
cons: Slow executive leadership, not a lot of room for growth, the system is very big and is hard to make changes in

pros: teaching institution with great mentorship
cons: continuous added volume without compensation.

pros: UMP has good benefits and a great retirement match
cons: Poor leadership development. My growth felt stunted because my supervisor didn't have the capacity or training from up above to support me and develop my skills. I disliked that I felt discouraged to reach out to anyone else other than my direct supervisor for support.

review_title: An ambitious facility that has withheld resources from the building
job_title: Surgical Team Assistant in Minneapolis, MN

Salary
Benefits 
Flexible time off
Friendly team

Feels like leadership doesn’t listen to staff at all

pros: Dedicated Coworkers, Stable hours, good benefits
cons: Constantly growing workload, Cross Training in multiple departments

pros: friendly environment, benefits, decent work hours
cons: very little chance of moving up within the company, so you either leave or stay in the same position for years on end

job_title: Certified Registered Nurse Infusion in Chicago, IL
pros:
Great patients
great hours and benefits

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant (CMA) in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Good hours, Good Pay, Good benefits
cons: Kind of confusing at times.

pros: UMP values and employs cutting edge research and innovative care models. The majority are caring, respectful and collaborative providers and care teams. Senior management reads and considers patient and visitor feedback, making adjustments as needed. UMP works towards its vision and mission. Providers spend quality time with patients, do thorough evals, listen to patients and answer their questions. (Many of our patients are complex and have several co-existing health issues, whereas some community clinics must quickly shuffle through a minimum number of patients per day). My family has personally seen several providers across family medicine and the specialty clinics and we have been very impressed with all but one physician. We were even so impressed with some physicians that we transferred care to UMP.
cons: Change is slow. Senior management doesn't truly value and consider employee feedback; they have a set vision and require providers, nurses and staff to continually adjust, even when those processes are not working and corrective feedback and suggestions are offered. A few providers have left to work elsewhere and some clinics choose not to be fully staffed during the new center's hours M-F from 7 am-7 pm and Sat. mornings; therefore, demand exceeds supply in some clinics, causing a few months of wait time for appointments. However, I can understand that specialty physicians, after several years of experience and expertise, do not necessarily desire to work evenings and weekends, so they may decide to work at another location.

pros: relationships within my team were great
cons: lack of direction from the whole company, people are dropping like flies. UMP/Fairview/UMN don't work together. Epic team is horrid.

pros: Great people to work with/Team atmosphere
cons: Low pay for the position

pros: Highly engaged faculty, busy practice.
cons: Mostly the cold weather, honestly.

job_title: Infusion Registered Nurse in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Ability to grow in company
cons: Management needs appropriate training like all professional positions

pros: Great people and atmosphere overall
cons: Poor management and very disorganized. Terrible turnover rate.

pros: Amazing physicians and staff. It feels like a family.
cons: Management is what messes this place up. Should never be a company for working moms. Managers work offsite. Staff cannot. Inconsistencies amongst departments. Disorganized.

job_title: Senior ETL Developer in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Work life balance, bonuses are good
cons: None so far , hope this continues

review_title: Good at first.  Horrible at the end.
pros: The manager that hired me and my co-workers.  The job itself.
cons: Managers that replaced my hiring manager were horrible! They made it an awful place to work.

job_title: RN Care Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Ok benefits for job that
cons: Poor management not good management

review_title: Can't believe how unprofessional and exploitative UMP is.
pros: It's a paycheck I guess.
cons:
If you are not in the union, UMP will walk ALL OVER you.  The UMP structure is a bit strange.  You can work in a department where some workers are union and others aren't. I happened to work for two different departments simultaneously.  I was not in the union. One dpt had union workers, the other had none.  World of difference in environments.  When I came up for performance review in the non-union dpt, though there had been zero complaints about my performance during the year, surprise surprise ... suddenly I wasn't making enough effort, I was choosing to LEAVE ON TIME for my personal life instead of "doing what it takes."  And I received no raise after a year of consistently showing up on time, contributing ideas, putting on a friendly face and really caring about helping our patients.  
 At the dpt with union, I got a great review and a raise.  Morale was noticeably better than the other dpt.

job_title: RN Care Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The staff I staff I work directly with and my department director are amazing. The surgeons I work with are also wonderful and supportive.
cons: Salaried at 40 hours, work more like 55-60 hours. There isn't enough staff to support the workload and the patient population. Management above my director doesn't see the need for more staff. In one year in our 8-10 specialty clinic, we have lost multiple RNs, LPNs, and CMAs due to the workload being asked of them. There isn't a centralized call center or triage so patients are being scheduled wrong or with wrong providers and being triaged poorly resulting in more ED visits. Not having a centralized triage and call center/ scheduling center results in patient safety concerns.

pros: Sadly, ump fails at any positive comments in its current state.  If you go back a few years, the company had great leadership but were sadly pushed out.   I would give this company zero but you require a star rating.
cons: Parking contracts are not discussed at interview and offer. Once you get started you find out that contracts are 2 years out! You can pay 12 dollars a day for a ramp that is close or park 1/2 mile for cheaper parking.  Leadership, has been turned over every year, new management has little experience leading, makes false promises, and takes credit for accomplishments made by the team but is quick to blame and point for fingers at others when things fail.  Reporting to HR concerns are brushed under the table and You are left on your own to figure out to deal with a vial director.   A director who does not met the minimum requirements of the job and has ruined everything since they started.   No direction, blaming others for failure, lies, and never being at work- if that’s what your looking for a director to be, Good luck.

review_title: Not worth putting up with the lack of quality management
pros: Amazing patients, decent hours, great retirement benefits.
cons: Awful health insurance options- no matter which plan you chose you will end up paying a ton out of pocket for minimal health care needs. Upper management seriously lacking compassion or moral ethics in their decision making, no concern for employee satisfaction with a huge emphasis on budget. Policies that are not set in stone,  followed when it benefits the budget and ignored when it may not benefit them. They take advantage of dedicated employees time and time again, stretch us so thin and don't take our questions or concerns seriously. Constantly telling staff, "we're working on it" or "we're looking into it" yet year after year, nothing comes of it and the same issues remain.

pros: Decent pay and good hours.
cons: Upper management is all about profit! They don't care how long you have been an employee for, they will eliminate your job if need be without understanding the importance of your role for patient care. They are broke now that Fairview has merged with Healtheast. UMMC wanted to take over FV but that didn't happen. FV is funding Healtheast now, which means UMP is going broke and they are making all sorts of cuts. I've been with the company for 4 years, and was just told by HR that my dept is being eliminated. The only way I can get my severance pay is to train the people who are replacing me for one whole month! What a slap on the face! Beware!

pros: Uniform allowance, helpful coworkers, nice building
cons: 9MAPLE GROVE) Mgmnt is positively awful. Bullying goes on all over the building - some even comes from mgmnt. Definite favoritism. Hired for one thing, required to do many many others. Change work hours no matter what employee wants. Toss employees into areas with no training. Rules change. Learn it one way - the next day you're in trouble for doing it that way. CRAZY high turnover. I've been there 3 years and it's almost all new staff. Just a real bad bad place to work. They do not value their employees. You're completely replaceable. They don't get to know anything about you - they treat you like robots. No help, but if you skip lunch or punch out late you get in trouble. Everything is about $$.

review_title: Not a sustainable career for most physicians
pros: Great clinicians, staff and RNs; but is hamstrung by an incompetent, insular management.
cons: Management is clueless about promoting excellence in clinical care, or reasearch. There seems to be a core set of people who shove decisions down the organization.  In my 5 or so years I workded there; very high turnover in clinical staff. Disorganised patient flow and process.  Minimal input from staff was taken on how to make things better. Seems like the senior management is playing its own political games and maximizing profits at the expanse of clinical care and staff. What a waste of resources and talent. Being in the twin cities with access to a highly talented workforce; they should be doing so much better.

pros: Competitive pay even if you don't have a college degree, excellent benefits compared to most employers, learning opportunities available, staff are generally friendly
cons: Very difficult to take time off, salaried staff expected to work in excess of 40 hours on a regular basis making work-life balance difficult, management allowed to scream and demean staff with no repercussions. My department had a pricey holiday lunch and then we all had to pay our own tab. It was very odd.

pros: Excellent learning opportunities with nationally recognized physicians. Physicians are willing to teach. Decent benefits.
cons: Top heavy senior management that is very disconnected from staff who are doing direct patient care. Continuous revolving door for middle management and staff. Very little recognition for excellent performance. Ridiculous merit based pay raise with unrealistic goals that don't apply to the employee directly.

review_title: Disorganized company, but I love working here
job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Because of its disarray, there's lots of opportunity to have an impact.  I like the benefits, salary, etc.  My boss is very laid back, big-picture kind of guy, lets you focus on your job without micromanaging you.  For me at least, there is pressure to perform, but it's tempered by the company's past failures to execute and so you're given more flexibility and understanding.  This is greatly appreciated.
cons: Suffers hugely from the core complexity of being stuck between the two 800lb. gorillas that are the U of M and Fairview.  This infects *everything*.

pros: Benefits packages are solid. PTO is very nice. The hours per week are stable and consistent with no nights or weekends.
cons: Supervisors have no one to answer to and are never held accountable. I have not even seen our upper management in months. They talk a big talk but it's very clear that they have a "closed door" policy.  I have never worked for a company that had this much turnover and disfunction. Unfortunately I see it affecting our patients' care on a regular basis.

pros: Most people you work with are awesome  and the providers are great.
cons: I worked at the Broadway  clinic and the management there is awful. They have no clue what is going on and change how things should be done when ever they feel like it.  The yearly uniform allowance comes every year and a half and the uniforms are ugly and one size  fits none.  Only letting 1 person have a day off at a time makes it hard to plan a vacation.

pros: The clinical team at Masonic is awesome! Caring volunteers, MDs, RNs, PAs, CMAs, phlebotomists, etc!! They are dedicated to providing the best care for the patients. Team work and community are big at Masonic. This clinic is operational & successful because the medical professionals do their jobs well. High-pay!
cons: Sadly, the clinic managers have no clinical background!!! They do not understand the operational logistics involved with actually RUNNING A CLINC. Training for staff is non-existent and accountability is lacking from the top tiers to the lowest ones. The clinic staff is always short-staffed so everyone is stretched very thin.

job_title: Health Records Technician in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I had a great supervisor who I wished I could stayed and worked for. Met great people who listened to my questions and needs.
cons: As a full time temp I made $16.00 an hour, they offered me the same kind of position at $14.00 an hour. Upper management is difficult, does not understand your job, and don't care about you in the slightest. They do not care about employees at all. We are numbers.

pros: Caring staff and some management, great, interesting patients, access to lectures and learning in academic setting, opportunities to take initiative and contribute to greater organization
cons: Minimal pay for work scope and expectations beyond what's reasonable for scheduled work hours.  Communication from mgmt. is inconsistent.  Workplace confidentiality - not always respected.  Hiring decisions seem to select least costly person, high turn-over on staff & mgmt. levels

review_title: Management by yelling is the norm here
pros: State of the art new building. Cream of the crop staff.
cons: I've never worked in an environment where management yells at its workers as much as this place. The company loses millions of dollars a year and they use it to keep the workers in a constant state of fear of losing their jobs. Lastly, all they served at the Holiday party was bread with a couple different spreads; disgraceful and demonstrates how much regard they have for the workers.

review_title: Burning out good employees without a care
pros: The clinical side of the business is great.  Wonderful physicians and hard working teams.
cons: The executive admin / business assistant team is in shambles.  Over half the team has left this year.  Those that go above and beyond are expected to do more, while the under-performers are coddled.  Hiring unqualified people, without any executive level experience, and expecting the seasoned employees to clean up their mistakes.  More effort is spent by management protecting the people that never should have had this position, while burning out the experienced assistants who are giving it their all.

pros: Opportunity to work with a team of caring and dedicated professionals. Most physicians are involved in innovative research, so it is an interesting environment to be a part of. Compensation is fair.
cons: Difficult to navigate through the UMPhysicians, Fairview, UMMC environment. Upper management is constantly trying to integrate the three companies with new initiatives, most of which results in added confusions and limited benefit. Communication between management and lower level employees is poor across all departments. Healthcare benefits are substandard for staff, better for physicians.

job_title: Clinical Care Provider in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Awesome patients, and medical facility staff
cons: This is a company that puts "policy" ahead of common sense. Seems to operate under the guise that all you need is the U of MN name somewhere and people will assume care is high quality, and people will want to be afficliated with the name. Staff is a revolving door from clinic staff to executive management and every level in between.

pros: I work in the ophthalmology clinic and the doctors and my coworkers are great.  It's a very interesting place to work especially for an COT who would like to get exposure to every sub specialty.
cons: The company is apparently not doing well right now.  We are told that UMPhysicians is massively in the hole and there is a hiring freeze.  We have had multiple staff members quit and have been unable to re hire for their positions.  It seems to be difficult to even recruit quality people to work here.  Getting to the office and the parking is an enormous pain.  Parking is partially paid for but the employee does pay for parking.  There isn't any room in the close ramps for new employees - they have to get on a waiting list for a closer ramp and park in one that isn't even on the U campus over a mile away and either walk or take a shuttle.  The upper management here seems to have no idea what is actually going on in the clinics, in my opinion.  There are so many "big picture" things they seem to work on that aren't relevant to the certain smaller clinics.  Our managers are in CONSTANT meetings and really don't have much of a presence in the actual clinics.  There is a lot of waste via purchasing equipment that is not wanted/needed and then on the flip side not purchasing things we do need.  For a university setting I would appreciate better equipment to work with - our topographers are a complete joke.  I don't know how we run a cornea clinic with the equipment we have.  Our wait times in the clinic are absolutely horrendous due to the ratio of staff-patients.  We charge a lot of money for eye examinations and our pay doesn't reflect that.  The benefits are decent but not nearly in line with places like Health Partners, Park Nicollet, Allina, Fairview, etc.  Those places all pay way more for ophthalmic technicians as well.  Overall it isn't a bad place to work, there are lot of things that need to be worked on but I'm hopeful they can change.  It would be a great place to start out and get a lot of experience if you don't mind the parking situation.

job_title: RN Care Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Excellent benefits package. Amazing providers, RN's and support staff.
cons: Completely dysfunctional administration. Management is too busy, and too far removed to know what is going on with their employees. A lot of gaps in patient care. The left hand has no idea what the right hand is doing. Many incongruencies.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Most of the staff clearly cared about patients and their experiences.  Great health insurance.  Stable hours.  If you are healthy and in need of good entry level experience, this is a great fit.  If you're down with unions this position was part of one while I was there.
cons: Management overall wasn't very aware of day to day function.  Outdated websites / contact information /tech, upper management  not looking to fix or improve with any urgency while I was there.  Not a lot of room / opportunity for growth.  Training structure varied by department, not always for the better.  Stable hours, but not flexible on when you take your breaks or if you have medical appointments (example, if your break time fell durring a rush period, you weren't supposed to push it back until the rush had passed). Management not supportive if you yourself have a chronic health condition or emergency.  Like anything some departments had great teams, others had 1 or 2 "bad apples" that would manipulate scheduling hours, etc... par for the course with humanity.  Challenging if you worked with Drs with complex schedules (teaching, surgery, clinic, etc) painful to have to cancel patient appointments last minute (happened with more frequency than I thought "professional" in my clinic at that time).  I honestly did not enjoy being part of a union, I felt those dues were a waste of my money for all the assistance I got and the cap that was put on my raises.

job_title: Senior Patient Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The job security in this company is very good.
cons: Below average pay, substandard benefits and a far too large work load vs. size of team ratio. This company seems very reactionary to the changing landscape of health care as well rather than being proactive.

job_title: Senior Complex Procedure Scheduler in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Able to work independently to get job done, supervisor and manager did not micromanage staff. Flexible hours and able to get OT on occasion.
cons: Not able to further my career with the company without a degree.  I was maxed out in the pay range for my position so I left for another company with opportunity to advance.

pros: Not applicable as there are NONE
cons: Let me count the ways; Management is the worst I have ever worked for, the HR department is a joke (recruiting is constant turnover and false promises are a way of life), their obsession with the CSC leads to complete ignorance of all the issues the Administrative Office is dealing with, the level of incompetent and under-qualified people they hire is mind-boggling. Those of us that work hard, get more work. Those that can't even handle their jobs and mess up constantly get praised.

review_title: Not enough give, too much take
pros: Great 401k/retirement package, high employer contribution percent
cons: This place expects too much of management. We put in 12 hour days and still can't get everything done that is expected of us. They are constantly coming up with new initiatives before previously implemented one's are completed.

job_title: Registered Medical Assistant in Saint Paul, MN
pros: I enjoy working with the people here.  University of MN Physicians is constantly improving and thriving to be competitive with other places.  Engagement teams are involved to help improve employees' survey.
cons: Medical benefits could be better for sure. I want to see more room for opportunity or go up the ladder. Hard to take time off especially in my department - Out of 14 people only one person could take time off.

review_title: Decent Pay, Work Environment needs improvement.
pros: Working with caring and dedicated providers. Able build relationships and follow progress of families during their treatment. Physicians where multiply hat are involved in innovative research, so it is an interesting environment to be a part of.  Flexible scheduling.
cons: Poor communication, limited parking even with contract, management does not follow through when front-line employees voices concerns. Over worked, under staffed.

pros: University environment is young and lively, interesting cases. variety , make your own happiness
cons: The private sector pays more and see advice to management

review_title: RN—worst place I’ve ever worked in 2 decades
pros: Worked with an amazing team who gave so much
cons: Promotions given to people who don’t deserve them, not to people who do. Unethical behaviors, bullying is allowed. HR and Compliance do not protect employees. Management is clueless and leadership is never visible to the front line staff. All of this puts patients at risk and is unsafe! I would never recommend this place to another professional, or to patients who seek care.

pros: Benefits, specifically the 401K and the employer HSA contribution.
cons: Organizational instability. Management fails when listening to frontline staff.  Parking.  Expanded services while using a 9-5 allocated staffing model.  The growing pains of the Clinics and Surgery Center; after 2 years, still having systemic issues.

pros: Very little.  They are building a new facility and will be reducing long term staff in favor of technology.  No receptionists, no clerical staff no personal interactions with the patients.
cons: Management turnover is the highest seen.  No appreciation for employees and this will be shown during layoff time.  Soon to come though it's denied by all.  HR is worst ever and allow the bad and get rid of the good

job_title: Patient Care Supervisor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Good benefits, co workers,  holidays,
cons: Poor management,  clinics and surgery center is a disaster,  no money to change direction, restructure happens yearly,  not enough space to accommodate patients,  etc.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great physicians and patients, lots of learning opportunities
cons: Senior management is out touch with the staff.  Everything rolls down hill through middle management, feel really and for them.  All staffing decision are budget based so you are always working short handed.

job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Located on UMN campus East Bank, great location.
cons:
1. It's a terrible work environment.
A great amount of co-workers in that department treat other colleagues from same level or above them with consistent disrespect and disgrace behind their back.  (My co-worker smashes the phone and swears at our manager frequently after she calls her.) 

2. Working in this department was like working for a bad-tempered client.
Top level managers are all anesthesiologist background, but some of them are demanding, controlling in all aspects that leads to disastrous results, both in terms of work accomplishments and employees' development. 

My boss and manager tends to treat most non-doctor (admin) subordinates not as their associates, but rather as their servants. In the rare occasions of one-on-one times, they like to spend most time in talking vaguely about assigning a project, or educating, criticizing, rather than listening for feedbacks and suggestions.  

The same project could last for almost one year without progression, yet he refuses clarity and any advice from the lower level associates whose specialities are in that area, rather he mindlessly gives orders to both employees below his level and software company that provides the service. My boss was also rarely available for any followups with questions. It could take him one week to reply a phone call or an email, but whenever everything went wrong the subordinates were always the first ones to be blamed and criticized. (In my first two weeks working there, one of my co-workers was yelled at by our boss during a meeting for something she was not assigned and she ran out of the meeting crying.) 

3. There was no honesty or open communication in this department. 
Some people can choose their working hours but some cannot. The manager could abruptly change your working hours or office locations without concerning your own personal needs. Any negotiations or questionings were considered disobedience. 

4. Docs: IT Admins are not on Calls. 
I was working part-time for a while and full-time for a while. When I was working part-time while going the school full-time, I had a set of working schedule for 20 hours per week. But since the managers did not help me get a separate email account from my school's email, I have been receiving emails anytime from 6:20 am to 10:30 pm from doctors specifically directed to me asking to handle work-related issues.

pros: The best perk of working here is the teaching-learning environment.  The providers are always excited and willing to teach others.  This helps nurses and other team members to provide exceptional care for our patients.  We provide services and and specialty care like no other.  It's the best place I've ever worked!
cons: None - nowhere is perfect, but this place is close!

pros: Innovative organization that provides some outstanding medical care.
cons: Highly political organization, making it hard to deliver your best work.  Little appreciation for good work and little respect for most workers.

cons: If you are sick or your kids are sick, you can only take about 5 - 8 sick days in the whole year. If it's more than that, you get written up and can loose your job. Nobody cares about your family or you outside of work.
